author: sky.cactus
content: Keeping a client up and running is very much not free.  For some operations like miners it is a small cost relative to the rest of what they do but for someone like infura or alchemy, client running costs likely dominate OpEx.

author: edson.eth
content: You're right. I guess how much they value reliability would determine that approach. Not the best thing for everyone

author: edson.eth
content:
From my experience running Besu, from what I know what prevents someone from switching clients immediately in an emergency is having the client sync all blocks. Operators could possibly sync up to the latest month once a month, and stop running that client until needed. 

Or clients can work towards being developed in a way where they can more easily be swapped.

Just throwing ideas out there

Infura/Alchemy I believe spend most of their OpEx on running the clients and bandwidth to/from the clients, which means if they triple the number of clients they are running, they up to triple their OpEx.

author: sky.cactus
content: For something like EtherScan, I suspect their OpEx is in hitting their custom databases, not their clients.  I *suspect* exchanges are somewhere in the middle.

author: vorot93
content: <@301186049323958275> no, this is exactly what I meant. Second node does not mean more requests. Either the requests are split between the two, or the second node is kept as backup - in any case bandwidth stays the same.

author: sky.cactus
content: Oh, I was suggesting that the request is served by *all* nodes, and then the proxy would compare the results and respond if they matched.

author: sky.cactus
content: The problem with "just have a node ready to switch to as a backup" is that if 90% of critical infrastructure has Geth as primary and Geth has a consensus bug, then those people will all continue operating on the bad chain until a human intervenes.

author: sky.cactus
content: By having a proxy that compares results, the clients will stop responding as soon as consensus error occurs.

author: sky.cactus
content: I suppose for consensus issues you actually only need one copy of each in your infrastructure and then a mechanism for signaling the rest of your infrastructure to halt.  ü§î
